levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying a root word within a word that has a common suffix (-ing, -ed, -er).
levels.example_task: What is the root word in 'playing', 'jumped', 'taller'?
common_errors: Removing too many letters (e.g., saying the root of 'taller' is 'tal')
Not recognising that the root word's spelling may change when a suffix is added

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using root word knowledge to read and understand unfamiliar words with prefixes and suffixes.
levels.example_task: You encounter the word 'disagreement' in your reading. Break it down using your knowledge of root words.
levels.example_response: 'The root word is "agree". "Dis-" is a prefix meaning not or the opposite. "-ment" is a suffix that makes it a noun. So "disagreement" means when people don't agree.'
common_errors: Identifying the root but not connecting it to the meaning of the whole word
Breaking the word at the wrong point

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Applying root word knowledge systematically to decode and understand unfamiliar multisyllabic words in reading.
levels.example_task: Read this passage. Circle three unfamiliar words. For each, identify the root word and use it to work out the meaning.
levels.example_response: Child identifies words like 'uncomfortable' (root: comfort), 'disappearance' (root: appear), 'unbreakable' (root: break) and explains each meaning by analysing the root word and affixes.
common_errors: Identifying the root word but not using the prefix/suffix meanings to build the full definition
Misidentifying roots in words that look like they contain a familiar word but don't (e.g., 'carpet' doesn't contain 'car' as a meaningful root)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Tracing word families from a shared root and explaining how meaning shifts across the family, using this to learn new vocabulary efficiently.
levels.example_task: Starting with the root word 'port' (meaning to carry), generate a word family and explain how each word relates to carrying.
levels.example_response: 'Transport — carry across. Export — carry out. Import — carry in. Portable — able to be carried. Porter — a person who carries things. Deport — carry away (send someone out of a country). They all connect back to the idea of carrying.'
common_errors: Generating words that contain 'port' but aren't related to the root meaning (e.g., 'sport')
Listing word family members but not explaining the semantic connection

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising common prefixes (un-, re-, dis-) and knowing they change the meaning of the root word.
levels.example_task: What does 'un-' do to the meaning of a word? What does 'unhappy' mean?
levels.example_response: 'Un- makes it the opposite. Unhappy means not happy.'
common_errors: Knowing 'unhappy' means not happy but not being able to state the general rule about 'un-'
Not recognising that 'un-' is a prefix rather than just the first two letters

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using knowledge of Year 3 prefixes (dis-, mis-, re-, pre-, anti-, auto-, super-, sub-) to work out word meanings.
levels.example_task: Work out the meaning of these words using prefix knowledge: 'misbehave', 'rewrite', 'submarine'.
levels.example_response: 'Mis- means wrongly, so misbehave means behave badly. Re- means again, so rewrite means write again. Sub- means under, so submarine means under the sea.'
common_errors: Knowing the prefix meaning but applying it incorrectly to the whole word
Confusing prefix meanings (e.g., thinking 'dis-' means 'again')

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using prefix and suffix knowledge to read and understand new words encountered independently, including understanding how suffixes change word class.
levels.example_task: The text says: 'The inexplicable disappearance puzzled everyone.' Use your knowledge of prefixes and suffixes to work out 'inexplicable' and 'disappearance'.
levels.example_response: 'In- means not. Explain is the root (spelling changes). -able means able to be. So inexplicable means cannot be explained. Dis- means the opposite. Appear is the root. -ance makes it a noun. So disappearance is when something stops appearing — it goes away.'
common_errors: Identifying one affix but not all of them in a multi-affix word
Not recognising when the root word's spelling has changed

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining how prefixes and suffixes from Latin and Greek roots contribute to English word formation, and using this to learn new vocabulary rapidly.
levels.example_task: The prefix 'auto-' comes from Greek meaning 'self'. How does this help you understand: autobiography, autograph, automatic, automobile?
levels.example_response: 'Autobiography — writing about yourself (auto = self, bio = life, graph = writing). Autograph — your own writing/signature (auto = self, graph = writing). Automatic — acting by itself, without someone controlling it. Automobile — self-moving (auto = self, mobile = moving). Knowing the Greek root helps me figure out new words with "auto-" even if I haven't seen them before.'
common_errors: Knowing the prefix meaning but not connecting it to the Greek/Latin origin
Understanding individual words but not recognising the systematic pattern

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading common Year 3-4 exception words accurately using whole-word recognition.
levels.example_response: Child reads all five words correctly without needing to decode.
common_errors: Mispronouncing 'different' as 'dif-er-ent' (three syllables instead of two common in speech)
Reading 'favourite' as 'fav-or-ite' with emphasis on the wrong syllable

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading and spelling a growing number of Year 3-4 exception words, noting the unusual spelling patterns.
levels.example_response: Child spells all four words correctly.
common_errors: Writing 'suprise' — missing the first 'r' in surprise
Writing 'Febuary' — missing the first 'r' in February

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading and spelling Year 3-4 exception words accurately in context, including in dictated sentences.
levels.example_task: Write from dictation: 'It was early in February when a peculiar accident occurred on the busy centre of town.'
levels.example_response: Child writes the sentence with 'February', 'peculiar', 'accident', 'occurred', 'busy', 'centre' spelled correctly.
common_errors: Spelling 'occured' instead of 'occurred' — missing the double 'r'
Writing 'center' (American spelling) instead of 'centre'

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Identifying patterns within exception words and using etymology or mnemonics to explain and remember unusual spellings.
levels.example_task: The words 'island', 'knowledge' and 'knight' all have silent letters. Can you explain why these letters are there? Create a mnemonic for one.
levels.example_response: 'These silent letters are historical — they used to be pronounced in Old English or Middle English. "Knight" was once pronounced with the "k" sound: "k-nicht". "Island" has a silent "s" because it was influenced by the Latin word "insula" even though the English word comes from a different origin. Mnemonic for "island": An island IS LAND surrounded by water.'
common_errors: Creating a mnemonic but not understanding the etymological reason
Assuming silent letters are random rather than historical

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Attempting to decode a longer unfamiliar word by breaking it into syllables.
levels.example_task: Read this word: 'caterpillar'. Break it into smaller parts to help you.
levels.example_response: Child segments: 'cat-er-pill-ar' and blends to say 'caterpillar'.
common_errors: Guessing the word based on the first few letters (e.g., 'category')
Giving up without attempting to break the word down

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using multiple strategies (syllable splitting, root word identification, trying different pronunciations) to decode unfamiliar words.
levels.example_task: Read the word 'enthusiastically'. Try different strategies until it sounds like a word you recognise.
levels.example_response: Child tries: 'en-thoo-see-ast-ick-al-ee'... adjusts to 'en-thew-zee-AST-ick-lee' and recognises 'enthusiastically'.
common_errors: Trying one pronunciation and giving up if it doesn't sound right
Decoding each syllable correctly but being unable to blend them into the whole word

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Decoding unfamiliar polysyllabic words in context, flexibly trying different pronunciations and using meaning to confirm.
levels.example_task: Read this passage aloud. When you meet an unfamiliar word, use your strategies to work it out. I'll note which strategies you use.
levels.example_response: Child reads fluently, pausing at unfamiliar words, segmenting by syllable, trying alternative vowel sounds where needed, and checking that the decoded word makes sense in context.
common_errors: Decoding the word correctly in isolation but not checking it makes sense in the sentence
Relying on only one strategy (usually sounding out) rather than flexibly choosing strategies

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining decoding strategies to others and identifying when a word has been incorrectly decoded by checking meaning.
levels.example_task: Your partner decoded the word 'misled' as 'MY-zuld' (rhyming with 'drizzled'). Help them work out the correct pronunciation and explain why their first attempt was wrong.
levels.example_response: 'You've read it as one word, but it's actually two parts: "mis-led", like the past tense of "mislead". If you think about the meaning — to mislead means to lead someone the wrong way — then "mis" + "led" makes sense. Your pronunciation didn't match any word you know, which is a clue to try again.'
common_errors: Identifying the correct pronunciation but not being able to explain the decoding error
Not using meaning as a check on whether a decoded word is correct
